questiontext.text: Identify the converse of the statement: "If it rains either today or tomorrow then it will rain next week".

generalfeedback.text:
Recall that the converse of the implication \(A \implies B\) is \(B \implies A\). Let \(A\) be the statement "it will rain today", \(B\) "it will rain tomorrow" and \(C\) "it will rain next week."

then the given statement says \((A \vee B) \implies C\). Therefore the converse is \(C \implies (A \vee B)\), in English this reads "If it rains next week then it will rain either today or tomorrow."

answer.text: If it rains next week then it will rain either today or tomorrow.
If it rains next week then it will rain today but not rain tomorrow.
If it rains next week then it will rain tomorrow but it will not rain today.
If it rains tomorrow then it will rain next week.
If it rains today then it will rain next week.
If it rains next week then it will not rain either today or tomorrow.
